listitem.para: Use the following link to access and view the latest Komet release builds. Each release will include release notes that detail what updates were made.

Scroll down on this webpage to the latest release's "Assests" and select the installer based on your operating system and central processing unit chip, when appropriate (Mac M1 versus Mac Intel chip).
Save the download file to the location of your choice
The Komet installer will automatically create a "Solor" folder in your OSDisk (C:) -> Users -> [your personal user name] folder
From your browser’s downloads, open the Komet Installer file
If you experience a windows defender or other similar anti-virus pop-ups, proceed through the required steps to confirm the download
A message will pop up asking if you want to run the Komet Installer File, click "Run"
On Mac, run the installer and follow the onscreen installation instructions until installation is complete

Once complete, you should see a pop-up, but if nothing automatically appears, you can verify the install was successful by searching in your applications folder or your Operating System’s search feature for the Komet app

For Windows, go to your search bar or apps folder and search for “Komet”. For Mac, go to your applications folder or press Command+space, search for Komet, and run the latest desktop version of Komet. The application will be named Komet [version number], so for example "Komet 1.48.0"
The below Komet Startup window will open. Ensure the Data Source select is “Open SpinedArrayStore”
Select the data source you would like to use and click “Ok” in the bottom right and proceed to Step 8
If you do not see a data source, copy and paste the zip file containing the desired data to the OSDisk (C:) -> Users -> [your personal user name] -> Solor folder

Right click the desired data zip file and select "Unzip Here" so the data is stored in the Solor folder. Ensure the unzipped data files are placed directly in the unzipped data folder, not inside any subfolders within the unzipped data folder
Exit and re-open Komet. Change the data source to “Open SpinedArrayStore”; your data source should now appear
Select the data source you would like to use and click “Ok” in the bottom right
Komet will open to the landing page
As a user, you can start a session by clicking "New Project Journal"
The Project Journal will open to the default view with the Navigation and Search functionality in the left-hand bar and the detail viewer in the center.

section.title: How To Find A Concept
section.para: Users may want to search for concepts to see concept details, pertinent relationships, and associated authoring information.

listitem.para: To find a concept, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal, and select the comment icon in the left-hand bar
Type the keyword or concept name into the search bar at the top of the left-hand panel to find a concept

Results containing the keyword will populate in the field below the search bar. You can also use a "+" symbol in front of each word when you know exactly what concept you are searching for to return only exact matches (e.g., +chronic +lung +disease)
To view a concept, double click on a search result, drag the concept to the center panel, or right click a concept and select "Populate Concept Option"
You can click the comment icon at the top of the left-hand bar again to minimize the search panel for more space (this can be done for any icon in the left-hand bar)
Toggle the "Properties" button on and use the icons at the top right-had side of the concept window to view various details and information about the selected concept
The concept window can display additional information, including:
Description Semantic with language and dialect
Relationship destination and relationship origin
EL++ Stated terminological axioms showing hierarchical relationships
To view hierarchical relationships, select the Navigator icon in the left-hand bar
Drag the desired concept from the Axioms section into the Hierarchical Relationships panel. Inferred navigation pattern information will appear on the left-hand side.
Hierarchical Relationships can also be viewed in the center panel by toggling the "Properties" button on and selecting the "Hierarchy" icon at the top of the concept window
Utilize the arrows within either Hierarchical Relationships panel to collapse or expand relationships, as needed
Finally, you can view Hierarchical Relationships by clicking the pop-out icon in the Axiom section of the concept window

section.title: Viewing Versioning
section.para: Users may want to view concept versioning to understand how a concept has evolved over time, including when certain characteristics or details were added or removed and when axiom changes were made.

listitem.para: To view versioning, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal, and follow the steps to view a concept in Section 1.4
In the tool ribbon at the top left of the concept window, click the Time Travel button
The Timeline panel opens to the right. The blue lines in the Timeline panel represent different data extensions.
Click the elipsis in the top right of the Timeline panel to see additional information on the Path and Extensions that the timelines represent
Toggle the "Properties" button on in the top right of the concept window
Then toggle the "Range" button on

Drag the top or bottom horizontal blue bars to view concept version information over a specified date range. When you define a specific time range, the History view only shows event details for event nodes within that time range
Selecting a specific node on the timeline will turn the node green and highlight information pertaining to that change or concept version
You can further narrow the versioning by selecting the "All" drop down arrow to filter historical events by Concept, Description, and Axiom changes.

section.title: Creating a Concept
section.para: Users may want to create a concept to represent new or emerging clinical conditions or create temporary concepts while Standards Developing Organizations create official representations. Creating a concept allows users to enter associated information like Status, Time, Author, Module, and Path (STAMP), stated relationships, and more.

listitem.para: To create a concept, first open a new journal, in an existing and open journal, and click the "+" icon at the top of the Komet window and select "New Concept"
A new concept template will appear

To add STAMP properties of the new concept, select the ellipsis in the top right of the concept window and select the appropriate options within each drop down menu to edit the appropriate information for STAMP
Select the pencil icon on the right-hand side of the description section of the concept window to add a description
Select "Add Fully Qualified Name" and fill out the necessary information
When complete, scroll to the bottom of the panel and select "Submit"
Select the pencil icon again on the right-hand side of the description section to add an Other Name, as needed
Finally, select the pencil icon on the right-hand side of the axiom section of the concept window to add axiom information, including sufficient and necessary sets
Once you add a Sufficient of Necessary Set, it will appear in the Axioms section, where you can thens elect the pencil icon to add another Sufficient or Necessary set
After a Sufficient or Necessary set is added, a unique identifier will automatically be generated for your concept
Your concept will then appear in the concept search bar on the left hand side

section.title: Editing a Concept
section.para: Users may want to edit or modify a concept to reflect new and emerging real-world data or real-world evidence.

listitem.para: To edit a concept, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal, and find the concept you want to edit, double-click or drag the concept into the main viewing window, and turn the "Properties" button is toggled on.

Of note, if you are editing a concept you just created, you must first exit out of the concept window, find the new concept with the search feature, and then double click or drag the new concept back into the viewing window
You can directly edit a Fully Qualified Name or Other Name by clicking the respective name in the concept window
You can also select the "Add/Edit" pencil icon at the top right of the concept viewing window
Selecting "Edit Description" leads to two additional options
Selecting "Edit Fully Qualified" allows you to edit the selected concept's Fully Qualified Name and associated information
Selecting "Add Other Name" allows you to add a new description of the concept and associated information

Once you have changed the Fully Qualified Name or added an Other Name, scroll to the bottom of the edit panel and select submit. You can also write a comment to provide additional information on the changes.
Axioms can also be edited at various hierarchical levels by selecting the Pencil Icon next to the Axiom's concept and selecting the appropriate action from the drop down menu

section.title: Creating and Editing a Pattern
section.para: Users may want to create or edit a pattern to provide additional, important, context to a concept.

listitem.para: To create a new pattern, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal, and click the "+" icon at the top of the Komet window and select "New Pattern"
A new pattern editing window will appear, where you can select the ellipsis to add STAMP information
Next, select the Pencil Icon in the Pattern Definition section to add Semantic Purpose and Semantic Meaning

Concepts for both Semantic Purpose and Semantic Meaning can be found by selecting the Comment Icon on the left-hand bar and searching for desired Concepts. These can then be drag-and-dropped into Purpose or Meaning.
Once you have added concepts for Semantic Purpose and Semantic Meaning, click "Done" in the Properties panel
Next, select the Pencil Icon in the Description section to add a Fully Qualified Name and/or Other Name
Selecting "Add Fully Qualified Name" or "Add Other Name" opens the Properties panel for users to fill out various components of a Pattern's description
Once all necessary components are complete, select "Done"
If needed, select the Pencil Icon in the Fields section to add additional information. This step is optional

Once you have entered all the necessary details, click "Done". You can add additional Fields by clicking the Pencil icon again. These additional fields will be labeled with increasing Field Order numbers.
You can edit Fields by right clicking the desired Field Number in the Fields Section and selecting "Edit"
Once all sections have been completed for the Pattern, select the Globe icon to save the pattern

If completed properly, an identifier will be generated underneath the Pattern name in the concept window and the Pattern will appear within the list of Patterns that can be accessed by selecting the Concept Navigator icon on the left-hand bar and then Patterns.

section.title: Creating LIDR Data
section.para: Users may want to create a device extension, which can help tie additional information related to devices to the concept that extend beyond the original terminology standard requirements. In this case, we are authoring a LIDR record

listitem.para: To create LIDR data, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal and select the "+" at the top of the project journal
This will open a blank LIDR template to fill out
First, start by selecting the ellipsis on the right had side to create a STAMP for the LIDR concept
Selecting Status, Module, and Path will open a dropdown menu of possible choices for users to select from when authoring STAMP
Once you have selected the Status, Module, and Path, click the LIDR Viewer window and the properties will populate
Next, select the pencil icon in the Device(s) Summary section to open the Properties section and add a device

Users can search for a device, manually enter a device, or drag and drop a device from the Hierarchical Relationship tab in the left-hand bar. Users can navigate to the "Tinkar root concept" → "Model concept" → "Device" section to click and drag a device to the LIDR Viewer Properties panel
The device will appear in the Device Summary Properties panel
Once you click "Done" in the bottom right of the Device Summary Properties panel, it will appear in the LIDR Viewer window

Finally, select the pencil icon in the LIDR Record Details section to open the Properties section and add Analytes, Targets, Results, and Specimens. Similar to the Device Summary, Analytes, Targets, Results, and Specimens can be searched for, manually added, or dragged from the Hierarchical Relationship tab in the left-hand bar. These can be found in "Tinkar root concept" → "Model concept" → "Analyte", "Targets", "Result Constraints", and "Specimens" respectively
Users can add multiple Targets, Result Constraints, and Specimen but are limited to a single Analyte.
Once you click "Done" in the bottom right of the LIDR Record Details panel, it will appear in the LIDR Viewer window
The Analyte, Results, and Specimens within the LIDR Record Details section can be expanded for more information

You can then go to the Hierarchical Relationship tab in the left-hand bar, locate the device you created, right click, and select "LIDR Viewer" to view the concept in the LIDR Viewer window without having to re-enter all of the data

section.title: Exporting Datasets
section.para: Users may want to export a dataset to share some of their authoring work with other users

listitem.para: To export a dataset, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal select "File" in the upper left-hand side of the application window and select "Export Dataset"

Complete all of the necessary fields, including Time Period. Time Period can be any changes made during the Current Date or can be changed to a Custom Range to export changes made during a specific time period
Once you have entered all pertinent information, click "Export" and a progress bar will appear in the bottom left-hand side of Komet

section.title: Importing Datasets
section.para:
Users may want to import a dataset to view changes or authoring done by other users
To import a dataset, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal select "File" in the upper left-hand side of the application window and select "Import Dataset"
Once the following pop-up opens, drag your desired dataset into Komet or browse for the specific files and click "Import"
Import Dataset
Once you select "Import", a progress bar will appear in the bottom left-hand side of Komet
Importing

section.title: Git Sync
section.para: Users may want to use Git Sync to connect to their GitHub account in the Komet application so they can pull and sync change sets to a repository that they have created

listitem.para: To get started, you will need to be signed into your personal GitHub account. If you do not have an account, create one at GitHub

Next, create a Personal Access Token (PAT), which is a secure alternative to your password when authenticating, by logging into your GitHub account, selecting your user icon in the top-right hand corner of the page and selecting "Settings". Instead of entering your password in Komet, you will use the PAT, which is a unique, long string of characters, to authorize your actions
Now go to "Developer Settings"
Select "Personal access tokens"
Select "Tokens (classic)"
From the Generate New Token dropdown, select "Generate new token (classic)"
You will now be prompted to enter your password or authentication

You will need to enter a note (this note should help you differentiate this token from other similar tokens), under "Select scopes" select "repo", and then select "Generate token" at the bottom of the page
You will then be redirected to your newly created token, where you should copy and save the token number (using the copy icon next to the passkey) for a later step

section.title: Creating a Repository
section.para: Users will need to create a repository (repo) in their personal GitHub account to pull or sync change sets from Komet to GitHub

listitem.para: Select the your user icon in the top left corner and navigate to "Your repositories"
Select "New" to create a new repo

You will then need to name the repo (it is suggested to chose a name that will help identify the work you are doing), choose if you would like it to be a "Public or "Private" repo, and select "Add a README file" before selecting "Create Repository"
Select the green "Code" button and, from the dropdown menu, ensure "HTTPS' is selected. Then copy the repository web address and save for a later step

section.title: Using Git Sync
section.para: There are several functions of Git Sync that a user may want to use in Komet;

listitem.para: Info - Connects Komet to GitHub without pulling or syncing any changesets
Pull - Pulls the changesets from the GitHub repo that the connection was made with, loads them into Komet and then automatically runs the Reasoner.
Sync - Pulls the changesets from the repository, loads them into Komet, runs the Reasoner, and then pushes the changesets to the repository.

To use Git Sync Info, first open a new journal with the desired database you would like to use to generate a change set. The Komet landing page will open and the GitHub Status will show as disconnected
Select "Exchange" in the top left-hand side of the application window and select "Info"

Fill in the various fields that appear in the Info window and then press "Connect"; Git URL is the URL we saved in an earlier step, Git Email is the personal email you used to create your GitHub account, Git User Name is your personal GitHub username that you created, and Git Password is the repository passkey that we saved in an earlier step.
When done correctly, you will see the GitHub Status showing as "Connected" with a progress popup window appearing

To use Git Sync Pull, first open a new journal with the desired database you would like to use to generate a change set. From the landing page, select "Exchange" in the top left-hand side of the application window and select "Pull"
Any change sets that were in the GitHub repo will then be pulled into Komet and a progress popup will appear

To use Git Sync Sync, first open a new journal with the desired database you would like to use to generate a change set. From the landing page, select "Exchange" in the top left-hand side of the application window and select "Sync".
Of note, you will need to complete the steps outlined in Git Sync Info first.
You will see the below popup while the Sync processes

To ensure the Sync completed successfully, go to the repository you created earlier to validate that the change sets were successfully completed. This process can take a minute or so, as the changesets are pushed to GitHub

section.title: Running the Reasoner
section.para: Users may want to run the pertinent reasoner to update the inferred relationships, based on the stated relationships, that the author enters for a concept, to update the Hierarchical Relationship tab in the left-hand bar with manually entered LIDR result names, to detect equivalences, and more.

listitem.para: To run the reasoner, first open a new journal, or in an existing and open journal select a concept, and select the Reasoner icon at the top of the concept window
You can also open the Reasoner panel by selecting the Reasoner icon in the left-hand tool ribbon
Select the drop down menu in the top left of the Reasoner panel and select "Run Full Reasoner"
The reasoner may take up to a few minutes to successfully run, you should see the reasoner running in the activity tab

Once finished, the reasoner will generate results in the Reasoner Results tab. Results include concept size, cycles, orphans, and equivalences. These equivalences can then be expanded to see the specific equivalent concepts.
You can then compare the equivalent concepts by clicking on each concept, right clicking, and choosing "Compare Concepts"
This will then open all of the concept windows to allow users to understand the similarities and differences of each concept
